pageContext.claim: “There are more opportunities than ever before to get sidelined workers -- and these are people that lost jobs and have never gotten them back, but now they're coming back and very, very rapidly -- get these sidelined workers back into the labor force.”
pageContext.analysis: During the 2016 campaign, Trump often pointed sidelined workers —people who had given up looking for work — to back up his claim that the unemployment rate was fake. Looking at another variation of the unemployment rate, the U6 number, which takes this into account, unemployment was 7.4 percent in August, and has ticked up since then to 8.1 percent in January. In other words, they aren't coming back into the labor force “very rapidly.” Plus, it’s worth noting the U6 unemployment rate has fallen dramatically since it’s peak of 17.1 percent in October 2009.
